<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 103, 307, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space permeability of free space permittivity of free space elementary charge the Planck constant unified atomic mass unit rest mass of electron rest mass of proton molar gas constant the Avogadro constant the Boltzmann constant gravitational constant acceleration of free fall  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 102, 611, 121]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 135, 611, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{-7}\mathrm{Hm}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 170, 628, 189]]<|/det|>
\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 199, 623, 230]]<|/det|>
\[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 335, 606, 355]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 368, 606, 388]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 402, 606, 421]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 435, 625, 454]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 526, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 195, 536, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 235, 526, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 339, 613, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 425, 536, 460]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 500, 596, 520]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 529, 526, 556]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 531, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 636, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 517, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 715, 558, 733]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 747, 581, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 777, 536, 812]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 89]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 101, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 144, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 101, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
A solid cylinder of weight \(24 \text{N}\) is made of material of density \(850 \text{kg} \text{m}^{- 3}\). The cylinder has a length of \(0.18 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 139, 789, 268]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 279, 532, 297]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 307, 683, 325]]<|/det|>
Show that the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the cylinder is \(0.016 \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 482, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 146, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
The cylinder in **(a)** is attached by a spring to the bottom of a rigid container of liquid, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 549, 730, 752]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 765, 591, 784]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 794, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is in equilibrium with its bottom face at a depth of \(0.17 \text{m}\) below the surface of the liquid. The tension in the spring is \(8.0 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 839, 181, 857]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 839, 764, 857]]<|/det|>
Show that the upthrust acting on the cylinder due to the liquid is \(32 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 928, 920, 946]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 473, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 225, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
<form>density = ............................................... $\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m}^{-3}$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 144, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 256, 803, 275]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.3 shows the variation of the tension \(F\) with the length of the spring in \((\mathbf{b})\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 285, 710, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 486, 534, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 181, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 517, 920, 566]]<|/det|>
The tap at the bottom of the container is opened so that a fixed amount of liquid flows out of the container. The cylinder moves downwards so that the tension in the spring changes from 8.0N to 4.0N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 580, 737, 598]]<|/det|>
Determine the change in the elastic potential energy of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 734, 920, 753]]<|/det|>
<form>change in elastic potential energy = .................................................. J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 766, 181, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 766, 890, 784]]<|/det|>
More liquid is let out of the container until the updrust on the cylinder becomes 24 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 797, 683, 815]]<|/det|>
For the updrust of 24 N, determine the length of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 890, 920, 908]]<|/det|>
<form>length = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 920, 920, 938]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 442, 89]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by work done.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 794, 183]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (a) to show that the SI base units of energy are \(\mathsf{kg}\mathsf{m}^2\mathsf{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 273, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 803, 323]]<|/det|>
A metal rod is heated at one end so that thermal energy flows to the other end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 715, 338]]<|/det|>
The thermal energy \(E\) that flows through the rod in time \(t\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 343, 571, 377]]<|/det|>
\[E = \frac{cA(T_1 - T_2)t}{L}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 384, 544, 403]]<|/det|>
where \(A\) is the cross-sectional area of the rod,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 400, 663, 419]]<|/det|>
\(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) are the temperatures of the ends of the rod,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 415, 430, 433]]<|/det|>
\(L\) is the length of the rod,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 180, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>and</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 432, 346, 450]]<|/det|>
c is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 432, 481]]<|/det|>
Determine the SI base units of \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 740, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
<form>SI base units .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 771, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 285, 90]]<|/det|>
Define velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
A remote-controlled toy aircraft is flying horizontally in a wind. Fig. 3.1 shows the velocity vectors, to scale, of the wind and of the aircraft in still air.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 207, 616, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 435, 532, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 920, 501]]<|/det|>
The velocity of the aircraft in still air is \(42 \text{ m s}^{-1}\) to the north. The velocity of the wind is \(23 \text{ m s}^{-1}\) in a direction of \(54^{\circ}\) east of south.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 680, 532]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the resultant velocity of the aircraft.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 744, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<form>magnitude of velocity = ............................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 744, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The engine of the aircraft in **(b)** stops. The aircraft then glides towards the ground with a constant velocity at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as illustrated in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 112, 784, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 291, 591, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 322, 920, 356]]<|/det|>
The aircraft has a weight of \(46\mathrm{N}\) and travels a distance of \(280\mathrm{m}\) from point X to point Y. The change in gravitational potential energy of the aircraft for its movement from X to Y is \(6100\mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 369, 442, 387]]<|/det|>
Assume that there is now no wind.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 183, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 400, 346, 419]]<|/det|>
Calculate angle \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 603, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... \(^\circ\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 635, 181, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 635, 845, 653]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnitude of the force acting on the aircraft due to air resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 804, 920, 823]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The aircraft in **(c)** travels from X to Y in a time of 14 s. Fig. 3.3 shows that, as the aircraft travels from X to Y, it moves directly towards an observer who is standing on the ground.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 112, 865, 305]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 320, 591, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
The aircraft emits sound as it travels from X to Y. The observer hears sound of frequency \(450\mathrm{Hz}\). The speed of the sound in the air is \(340\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 703, 417]]<|/det|>
Calculate the frequency of the sound that is emitted by the aircraft.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 631, 920, 649]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 70, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
An \(\alpha\) -particle moves in a straight line through a vacuum with a constant speed of \(4.1 \times 10^{6} \text{m s}^{-1}\). The \(\alpha\) -particle enters a uniform electric field at point A, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 112, 752, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 250, 532, 269]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 282, 920, 317]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha\) -particle continues to move in the same straight line until it is brought to rest at point B by the electric field. The deceleration of the \(\alpha\) -particle by the electric field is \(2.7 \times 10^{14} \text{m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 329, 144, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 468, 348]]<|/det|>
State the direction of the electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 146, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 376, 409]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 545, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 577, 144, 594]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 448, 594]]<|/det|>
Calculate the electric field strength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 795, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
<form>electric field strength = ................................................. V m⁻¹ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 480, 89]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha \)-particle is at point A at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 918, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 399, 920, 418]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 431, 803, 448]]<|/det|>
A two-source interference experiment uses the arrangement shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 456, 769, 599]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 615, 591, 634]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 645, 905, 664]]<|/det|>
Light from a laser is incident normally on a double slit. A screen is parallel to the double slit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 677, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
Interference fringes are seen on the screen at distance \(D\) from the double slit. The separation of the centres of the slits is \(a\). The light has wavelength \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 724, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
The separation \(x\) of the centres of adjacent bright fringes is measured for different values of distance \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 527, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A resistance wire of uniform cross-sectional area \(3.3 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\) and length \(2.0 \text{m}\) is made of metal of resistivity \(5.0 \times 10^{- 7} \Omega \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 524, 135]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<label>(b)</label>

The ends of the resistance wire in **(a)** are connected to the terminals X and Y in the circuit shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
The cell has an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of \(1.50 \text{V}\) and internal resistance \(r\). The potential difference between X and Y is \(1.20 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 243, 628]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 643, 183, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

the current in the circuit

the internal resistance \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 905, 920, 923]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 905, 920, 923]]<|/det|>

A galvanometer and a cell of e.m.f. \(E\) with negligible internal resistance are connected to the circuit in **(b)**, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 327, 534, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 359, 920, 393]]<|/det|>
The resistance wire between X and Y has a length of 2.0 m. The galvanometer has a reading of zero when the connection P is adjusted so that the length XP is 1.4 m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 404, 435, 422]]<|/det|>
Determine the e.m.f. \(E\) of the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 572, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ....................................................... V [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 604, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
The circuit in Fig. 6.2 is modified by replacing the original resistance wire with a second resistance wire. The second wire has the same length as the original wire and is made of the same metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 763, 683]]<|/det|>
The second wire has a smaller cross-sectional area than the original wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 695, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
Connection P is adjusted on the second wire so that the galvanometer has a reading of zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 725, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether length XP for the second wire is shorter than, longer than or the same as length XP for the original wire when the galvanometer reading is zero.
